titleStmt.title: A New Simile for the Ladies

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: I often try'd in vain to find
A Simile for woman kind
A Simile I mean to fit 'em
In ev'ry circumstance to hit 'em
Through ev'ry bird and beast I went
I ransanckd ev'ry element
and after peping through all nature
To find so wimsical a creature
A cloud presented to my view
And strait this parallel I drew
clouds turn with ev'ry wind about
They keep us in suspense and doubt
yet oft perverse like women kind
are seen to scud against the wind
and not women just the same
for who can tell at what they aim
Clouds keep the stoutest mortals under
when bellowing they their thunder
So when the alarm bell is rung
of Zanthes everlasting toungue
the husband dreads its loudness more
Then lightening flash or thunders roar
clouds weep as they do without pain
and what are tears but womens rain
the clouds about the welkin roam
and ladies never stay at home
The clouds build castles in the Air
A thing peculiar to the fair
for all the schemes of their forecasting
are not more solid or more lasting
A cloud is light by turns & dark
so is a lady with her spark
now with a sudden pouting Gloom
she seems to darken all the room
again she's pleas'd her fears beguild
and all is clear when she has smil'd
In this they're wondrously alike
I hope the Simile will strike
Tho in the darkest dumps you veiwview e'm
Stay but a moment you'll see thro 'em
The clouds are apt to make reflexion
and grequently produce infection
So Caelia with small provocation
blasts ev'ry neighbours reputation
The clouds delight in Gawdy show
for they like ladies have their bow
The Gravest matron will confess
That she herself is fond of dress
observe the clouds in pomp array'd
what various colours are display'd
the pink the rose the violets dye
In that Great drawing room the sky
how do these differ from our Graces
In Garden silks brocades and laces
are they not such another sight
when met upon a birth day nightThe Clouds delight to change their fashion
Dear ladies be not in a passion
nor let this whim to you seem strange
who ever'y hour delight in change
In them and you alike are seen
The sullen symptoms of the spleen
The moment that your vapours rise
We see them dropping from your eyes
In evening fair you may behold
The Clouds are fringed with borrowd Gold
and this is many a ladys case
who flaunts about in borrowd lace
Grave matrons are like clouds of snow
their words fall thick and soft & slow
while brisk coquets like rattling hail
our ears on ev'ry side assail
clouds when they intercept your sight
deprive us of celestial light
so when my Cloe I pursue
no heaven besides I have in veiw
Thus on Comparison you see
in ev'ry instance they agree
so like so very much the the same
that one may Go by t'others name
let me proclaim it then aloud
that ev'ry woman is a cloud613-135F
